titleproper.value:
Guide to the Matthias B. Tallmadge Papers
                    <lb/> 1715-1868
                    <lb/>
                    <num>MS 612</num>

author.value: Finding aid prepared by Christine George

creation.value:
This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit
                <date>2011-08-03T10:47-0400</date>

abstract.label: Abstract
abstract.value: Matthias B. Tallmadge was the fifth judge for the District of New York and the first judge for the Northern District of New York. His papers include correspondence from the Tallmadge family, as well as many prominent individuals from the period, both related and unrelated to the Tallmadges. The papers also include materials from Tallmadge's tenure in the District of New York and later the Northern District of New York.

p.value: This collection should be cited as the Matthias B. Tallmadge Papers, MS 612, The New-York Historical Society.

The third series contains various notes and ephemera that make up an interesting assortment of items that highlight aspects of Tallmadge’s life. These items include references to religion, finances, and opinions on slavery. It is not a very large series.

dsc.value:
Series I: Correspondence 2 1 3 4 1715-1868, undated Scope and Content

Within this series, are three subseries. For the most part, the correspondence is arranged by the person who received it and then chronologically. At some point, a portion of the correspondence was mounted. There does not appear to be a particular reason why some of these letters were mounted and some were not.

 Subseries A: Matthias B. Tallmadge Correspondence 1 1 1787-1819, undated Scope and Content

Subseries A consists of Matthias B. Tallmadge’s correspondence. Overwhelmingly this subseries consists of letters Tallmadge received. There is one small folder of letters sent by him to individuals outside of his family and members of his extended family. Many of these letters are from his wife, Elizabeth Clinton Tallmadge. Of note, there are letters from George Clinton, Theodorus Bailey, Ephraim Snow, David Thomas, and Stephen Gano. Also of interest are several threats anonymously sent to Tallmadge while he sat on the bench. Two are from 1809, one of which contains an explicit threat against Tallmadge’s children.

 Matthias B. Tallmadge -- Letters Received 1 1 1787-1803 Matthias B. Tallmadge -- Letters Received 1 2 1804-1806 Matthias B. Tallmadge -- Letters Received 1 3 1807-1808 Matthias B. Tallmadge -- Letters Received 1 4 1809-1812 Matthias B. Tallmadge -- Letters Received 1 5 1813-1814 Matthias B. Tallmadge -- Letters Received 1 6 1815-1816 Matthias B. Tallmadge -- Letters Received 1 7 1817-1819 Matthias B. Tallmadge -- Letters Received 1 8 undated Matthias B. Tallmadge -- Letters Sent 1 9 1806-1817, undated Matthias B. Tallmadge -- Mounted Letters Received 2 1 1802-1807 Matthias B. Tallmadge -- Mounted Letters Received 2 2 1808-1810 Matthias B. Tallmadge -- Mounted Letters Received 2 3 1811-1819 Matthias B. Tallmadge -- Mounted Letters Received 2 4 undated Subseries B: Elizabeth Clinton Tallmadge Correspondence 1 1800-1824, undated Scope and Content

Subseries B contains correspondence to Tallmadge’s wife, Elizabeth Clinton Tallmadge. Many of the letters are from Tallmadge himself as well as their sons George Clinton Tallmadge and Charles William Tallmadge. There are also letters from a woman who was a missionary in India in the early nineteenth century.

 Elizabeth Clinton Tallmadge -- Letters Received 3 1 1800-1809 Elizabeth Clinton Tallmadge -- Letters Received 3 2 1810-1812 Elizabeth Clinton Tallmadge -- Letters Received 3 3 1813-1814 Elizabeth Clinton Tallmadge -- Letters Received 3 4 1815 Elizabeth Clinton Tallmadge -- Letters Received 3 5 1816-1817 Elizabeth Clinton Tallmadge -- Letters Received 3 6 1818-1819 Elizabeth Clinton Tallmadge -- Letters Received 3 7 1820-1822 Elizabeth Clinton Tallmadge -- Letters Receieved 3 8 1823 Elizabeth Clinton Tallmadge -- Letters Received 3 9 1824 Elizabeth Clinton Tallmadge -- Letters Received 3 10 undated Elizabeth Clinton Tallmadge -- Letters Received 3 11 undated Elizabeth Clinton Tallmadge -- Mounted Letters Received 2 5 1803-1809 Elizabeth Clinton Tallmadge -- Mounted Letters Received 2 6 1810-1813 Elizabeth Clinton Tallmadge -- Mounted Letters Received 2 7 1814-1824 Elizabeth Clinton Tallmadge -- Mounted Letters Received 2 8 undated Elizabeth Clinton Tallmadge -- Mounted Letters Received 2 9 undated Subseries C: Tallmadge Children Correspondence 1 3 1805-1868, undated Scope and Content

Subseries C consists of correspondence received by the Tallmadge children. The bulk of this correspondence is to eldest son, George Clinton Tallmadge.

 George Clinton Tallmadge -- Letters Received 4 1 1805-1815 George Clinton Tallmadge -- Letters Received 4 2 1817-1819 George Clinton Tallmadge -- Letters Received 4 3 1820-1823 George Clinton Tallmadge -- Letters Received 4 4 undated Charles William Tallmadge -- Letters Received 4 5 1812-1824, undated Theodore Bailey Tallmadge -- Letters Received 4 6 1815-1818, undated Elizabeth Matthias Tallmadge -- Letters Received 4 7 1828-1868, undated George Clinton Tallmadge -- Mounted Letters Received 2 10 1808-1821 Elizabeth Matthias Tallmadge -- Mounted Letters Received 2 11 1835-1836 Subseries D: Other Family and Friend Correspondence 1 3 1715-1849, undated Scope and Contents note

Subseries D consists of correspondence received and sent by various members of the extended family, both on the Tallmadge and Clinton sides, and friends. There is a folder of correspondence received by George Clinton and his wife, Elizabeth Clinton Tallmadge’s mother, Cornelia Tappen Clinton. There are letters sent from Nathaniel Pitcher Tallmadge and a small folder of letters of introduction, both for Tallmadge and to him.

 Charlotte Horton Rowe -- Letters Received 4 8 1816-1824, undated Correspondence Received and Sent by Members of the Tallmadge and Clinton Families 4 9 1715-1849 Letters of Introduction 4 10 1811-1820, undated Unidentified Correspondence 4 11 1803-1811, undated Cornelia Tappen Clinton -- Mounted Letters Received 2 12 1768-1777, undated George Clinton -- Mounted Letters Received 2 13 1772-1794 Mounted Correspondence Received and Sent by Members of the Tallmadge and Clinton Families 2 14 1772-1837, undated Series II: Legal 5 6 1772-1829, undated Scope and Content

This series focuses on Tallmadge’s tenure as a district court judge and is divided into three subseries. It consists of official documents from the court, lawyers, and witnesses. There are also a large number of handwritten notes on cases heard in the court. This series does not cover Tallmadge's entire tenure on the bench, but it offers a sampling of the cases he heard. At some point, a portion of the documents and notes were mounted. There does not appear to be a particular reason why some were mounted and some were not.

 Subseries A: United States v. Smith and Ogden 2 1806, undated Scope and Content

Subseries A contains materials from U.S. v. Smith and Ogden. This case concerned William S. Smith and Samuel G. Ogden's alleged involvement with the Miranda Affair, which would have been a violation of the Neutrality Act of 1794. The Act provided that no American should start war against a country the United States was at peace with. There are official documents from the case as well as handwritten notes. Of particular note are the letters from attorneys stating that Secretary of State James Madison and Secretary of the Navy Robert Smith would not testify in the case.

 Mounted Notes on the Case 2 15 1806, undated Mounted Documents Written by Lawyers and Witnesses 2 16 1806, undated Mounted Subpoena and Judicial Rulings 2 17 1806, undated Mounted Jury Charge 5 1 undated Subseries B: Court Documents 1772-1822, undated Scope and Content

Subseries B contains a variety of official materials. There are affidavits from cases heard from 1807-1810. Of note among these affidavits are several pertaining to the illegal importation of slaves including affidavits from William L. Lawrence and Anthony Anthe, both dated March 15, 1810 and Isaac Sherman’s dated March 17, 1810. There are a variety of other official documents from the court, though none of them have a number close to that of the affidavits. Two cases have been given their own files because of the amount of documentation: William Jackson et al. v. Ship Frederick and U.S. v. Aquila Giles, Nicholas Fish, and Matthew Clarkson, in which the defendants were known Revolutionary War heroes.

 Affidavits 6 1 1807-1809 Assorted Court Documents 6 2 1802-1814, undated Mounted Affidavits 5 2 1807-1810, undated Assorted Mounted Court Documents 5 3 1772-1808, undated Mounted Petitions and Writs 5 4 1805-1812 Mounted Warrants and Extradition Order 5 5 1806-1811 Mounted Court Documents from William Jackson et al. v. Ship Frederick 5 6 1808 Mounted Court Documents from U.S. v. Aquila Giles, Nicholas Fish, and Matthew Clarkson 5 7 undated Subseries C: Handwritten Notes 2 2 1800-1813, undated Scope and Content

Subseries C consists of handwritten notes. There are some notes on administrative or financial matters, but the bulk of this subseries is made up of handwritten notes on cases before the court. Many of these cases were admiralty cases. As in the previous subseries, there is a certain amount of information from William Jackson et al. v. Ship Frederick and U.S. v. Aquila Giles, Nicholas Fish, and Matthew Clarkson and those cases are each given their own folder for notes.

 Administrative and Financial Notes 6 3 1800, undated Notes on Cases in New York District Court 6 4 1805-1807 Notes on Cases in New York District Court 6 5 1808-1809 Notes on Cases in New York District Court 6 6 1810-1813 Notes on Cases in New York District Court 6 7 undated Mounted Notes on Cases in New York District Court 5 8 1805-1808 Mounted Notes on William Jackson et al. v. Ship Frederick 5 9 1808 Mounted Notes on Cases in New York District Court 5 10 1809 Mounted Notes on Cases in New York District Court 5 11 1810-1813 Mounted Notes on Cases in New York District Court 5 12 undated Mounted Notes on U.S. v. Aquila Giles, Nicholas Fish, and Matthew Clarkson 5 13 undated Subseries D: Tallmadge Family Documents 2 1829, undated Scope and Content

Subseries D is very small and consists of personal legal instruments for the Tallmadge family property.

 Tallmadge Family Legal Documents 6 8 1829, undated Series III: Notes and Ephemera 5 6 1771-1825, undated Scope and Content

This small series, mostly not dated, provides a look into the Tallmadge family life. There are documents relating to finance and property as well as hymns and poetry. Of note in this series is the folder Hymns, Poetry, and Narratives. Within that folder is testimony from Susan Wright, one of the Clinton family’s slaves who became a Baptist. At some point, a portion of the documents were mounted. There does not appear to be a particular reason why some were mounted and some were not.

 Accounting Notes 6 9 1796-1825, undated Hymns, Poetry, and Narratives 6 10 undated Notes and Ephemera 6 11 undated Mounted Official Materials and Notes 5 14 1771-1776, undated Mounted Notes and Ephemera 5 15 undated
